ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We read a number of interesting perspectives on political communication, including historical case studies, and political science papers, and one work of fiction.

I learned more about the historical and practical application of political persuasion - both in government and in politics. I gained insights into the psychological and rhetorical devices that politicians have used to successfully communicate their message. I also learned more about party politics in the United States, and how that does or doesn't affect electoral outcomes.
Learned a lot about historical and current modes of American political communication
I learned a lot of information about how information can be manipulated in political contexts. I also learned several forms of persuasion as they have been studied in this context.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The assignments were great and a fun to do. The seminar discussion was a little halting sometimes, but I think that was largely because there were only 6 people in the class this year.
Strengths: excellent professor, great course readings, good class size for a seminar setting. Weaknesses: not enough time to cover all of the readings.
I wish the class included more about famous, effective communicators in comparative stylistic study

I think the writing assignments are very interesting and really gave me a lot of room to explore and apply what I learned.  The readings, however, were not very connected to course discussion, at times dense, and lacking contemporary political events.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Seminar discussion was fine on Zoom, no different than other courses.
Successful practices: occasional breakout rooms provided a nice change of pace. Practices that could be improved: more guided discussion when students are not as engaged through the virtual format.
I just wish Professor Henderson was a bit more responsive to emails in the beginning of the semester

I think the best discussions occurred when we had specific guided questions that helped us weave all the literature together. Breakout rooms were also pretty productive for getting students to participate.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed this class. The readings were generally interesting and the assignments were some of my favorite I've done at Yale.

Absolutely! This class is excellent for anyone that already has participated in or made observations about political campaigns and rhetoric and would like to actively discuss these themes in a historical and contemporary context, as well as larger discussions about electoral politics in general.
I think the topic of the course is very interesting but I would tell them to supplement their reading with current events.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A we only met over zoom for our seminar.
